children.subject:
As a math/CS double major interested in AI (not robotics) here’s my stab at answering Q2:

i would recommend declaring the double major, just so you can get priority in classes like math 104, but I wouldn’t double major even if you only have to take 1 class you don’t want to. I do think you might enjoy Math 113/H113 or Math 110/H110. I know math 185 is useful for physicists/engineers, so it might also be useful for robotics.

also for q3, I know math grad courses are pretty easy for undergrads to enroll in. 

I would also also recommend CS 194-26 computational photography! The class covers a few topics from computer vision and the textbook used for the course is good plus the class is really fun and interesting.

Comment on Q1: I've taken 189 and am currently in 126. In my opinion, 189 is not a good measure at all of how well one understands the content of 126. Other than using some basic probability concepts like MLE, MAP, and lots of Gaussians, I didn't feel that 189 heavily utilized probability.

Q2: Like Alex said, I would also recommend declaring math if you're interested in taking a few upper div math classes. The priority would definitely help. You probably don't need to double major, unless you want to work on the very mathematical side of research. I don't have much experience in robotics research, but I think the extent to which math upper divs would be useful to you is a function of how mathematical you want your research to be. Most papers in AI currently do not contain much math beyond basic linear algebra. However, there are also lots of Berkeley PhD students and professors who utilize more advanced mathematical methods to study the dynamics of neural nets and optimization. It depends on what you want to do.

history.content:
Most of us here at Berkeley EECS have taken all these courses in high school. It is common practice to start with grad courses first semester freshman year, ideally earlier. It seems you are a little behind here, tough luck.

----

Most of us here at Berkeley EECS have taken all these courses in high school. It is common practice to start with grad courses first semester freshman year, ideally earlier. It seems you are a little behind here, tough luck.

----

You don't have to apologize, people are just playing around since you're so ahead of the curve (you really are, not just saying that). Nobody actually thinks any less/bad of you because of it. People like to just meme about things. You shouldn't ever feel bad or apologize for that.

3: There's being ahead of the curve and then there's insinuating that you're better than an entire curriculum

^Can you people stop? OP is just trying to get advice on how to succeed like many people on this forum. I don't get why that's insinuating anything. @OP you did not do anything wrong.

Most of us here at Berkeley EECS have taken all these courses in high school. It is common practice to start with grad courses first semester freshman year, ideally earlier. It seems you are a little behind here, tough luck.

----

You don't have to apologize, people are just playing around since you're so ahead of the curve (you really are, not just saying that). Nobody actually thinks any less/bad of you because of it. People like to just meme about things. You shouldn't ever feel bad or apologize for that.

3: There's being ahead of the curve and then there's insinuating that you're better than an entire curriculum

children.subject: how to use waybackmachine?
https://web.archive.org/web/*/eecs189.org
Thanks!
Are you suggesting that it's possible to take CS 189 w/o having taken EE126/127, and/or do you *highly* recommend the other direction?

I would argue it is possible to take 189 without 126 and 127, and that the difficulty of the course is overestimated. However, that being said, you should have at minimum, a good enough foundation in linear algebra and probability to self-study any new foreign concepts used in an 189 lecture / note.
Also I should mention that taking 126 and 127 for the sole purpose of preparing for 189 is, again, overkilling it. Besides, both courses are interesting enough that you should take them regardless.

Thanks, I was also surprised at how it was often cited that it was very necessary to take either 126 or 127 for 189. I do plan on taking those regardless, just perhaps 189 first/concurrent for the ML knowledge.

Take 126 and 127 before 189. This semester's instructors do not even cover the material in 126 (MLE/MAP) but use it liberally under the assumption that you already know it, and mostly assume heavy optimization knowledge beforehand.

It's true that in the first couple of semesters, 189 did not really need 126 or 127, but the course will continually ramp up until 126/127 are absolute prerequisites.

Q1:

Take 126. First 3 weeks of 126 are a lot of CS70 review so it's unsurprising that you felt comfortable with it. Stat134 is not at the level of EECS126 and 'self-studying' classes varies from person to person. I took 126 after 189 and found it orders of magnitude more challenging.

Q2:

You don't need to double major, you can get into the classes reasonably well.

Q3: 

Yes. You generally need to have good grades in core classes/previous grad classes/research to get into them.

Q4: 

http://www.eecs189.org/static/notes/n4.pdf

http://www.eecs189.org/static/notes/n6.pdf

http://www.eecs189.org/static/notes/n7.pdf

Just read the notes and use waybackmachine to recover previous HWs and do those for practice. Or, take EECS126, which covers these topics indepth.

Hi, I am a junior and wants to get some advice about what classes to take next. I am planning to get a Bachelors in Computer Science.

Tech Classes taken: CS61A

Tech Classes taking: CS61B, CS70

Want to take: Any relatively low workload CS class so I can graduate on time.
It's more about social awareness - saying offhand that you find getting all A/A+'s in 3/4 techs easy in a forum where 99% of people can't do that is generally regarded as a dick move

Then what exactly is allowed for the OP to ask, if he's trying to get into a DL PhD, which by default from numbers is something "99% of people can't do"? 
What if he asked:

"How do I apply for XYZ fellowship" - this is even far worse: average applicants in these have a million A's in all classes

"How do I code this in tensorflow" - most people can't code in tensorflow. 

"Should I take grad class1 or grad class2" - again, most people...

"How do I negotiate salary" - again, most people don't have multiple offers...
He's definitely allowed to ask that, I'm just saying it could've been done in a better way. Hell, he's allowed to ask it the way he did, but don't expect people not to lightly joke about it

From the post on overheard, his post seemed very honest about everything. 

Now, if the OP was an unrepresented minority discussing advice about race-related issues, raising light jokes about this would be extremely offensive and we'd be up in arms. 

If the OP was someone who was struggling, lightly joking about this we'd be up in arms too.

But for some reason, it's okay to lightly joke about the hardworking, ambitious, and honest students? Say their needs don't need to be met? These are the same reasons some people blame the American secondary schooling system - it's okay to just bully anybody who is a hardworking person when he asks honest questions? Many Asian countries don't have this sort of culture - not China, not India, not Korea. 

Now this was just a small example, but as a warning, these are the sorts of things that make really talented people drop out of school, and there are so many cases of this already. It's a common theme that some talented people are actually some of the most aggressive/anti-authoritarian people out there, and it's probably partially this reason.

^same poster as above - 

Actually, it's not even as light as it sounds - someone posted the OP's statement into Overheard at Berkeley, which is seen by thousands and thousands of people. I'm pretty sure the OP now at least has some negative feelings toward the general student body here. If this were about a minority posting, probably the police and national headlines would get involved. Good job.

"It takes a village to raise a child" can be translated to "It takes a lot of encouragement and support to raise a scientist". Great - who here can explain to the public, as to why the student body of Berkeley discouraged a well-meaning person from pursuing science? Is this how you want to show "school pride" to the public? This is actually a very discouraging post to any ambitious high schooler looking at the page. 

This is worth a far more aggressive response now because someone has posted this to a very publicly viewed channel (with now ~1000 likes)

lmao wat. you realize that the people who are unironically elitist EECS master race are NOT the people trying to ask people to slow down. in fact they are actually more elitist and look down upon you if you don't take all these courses for example

seriously realize that it's not academic performance we're against (in fact I would argue most EECS people esp on this thread are very genuinely curious and ambitious), but rather this competitive toxic mindset and of gathering resume accolades in a public forum

"Actually, it's not even as light as it sounds - someone posted the OP's statement into Overheard at Berkeley, which is seen by thousands and thousands of people. I'm pretty sure the OP now at least has some negative feelings toward the general student body here. If this were about a minority posting, probably the police and national headlines would get involved. Good job." wtf are you saying

sounds like some vague racism about how this is reverse racism or something something "why is it ok for sjws to get mad about this but i can't be an elitist guy on EECS 101 and humble brag?? i guess I'm the victim!"

seriously stop trying to play the victim. underrep minorities and minorities in general struggle everyday in this country. and you want to make it seem like you're oppressed because people found it off-color that someone thinks challenging courses are way too easy for him??

@why do you want to be oppressed so much

this isn't bullying. this is calling out attention against elitism. i hope you realize most EECS berkeley students are against bullying people who do well in secondary school or school in general. like you're really reaching over here with all these straw men. i think if you're complaining about the vast majority of people, maybe you are the problem

Re: "underrep minorities and minorities in general struggle everyday in this country". Research is hard enough too and requires a lot of effort, support, and ambition. It's just as easy to derail someone from a research career with bad experiences as it is with a minority. Same concept applies here. 

Re: " this isn't bullying. this is calling out attention against elitism" - Please go back and read the post on Overheard. There is zero hint of bragging from the poster as opposed to him just telling his current situation, what he's done so far, and what needs to be done next. 

Re: "Rather this competitive toxic mindset and of gathering resume accolades" in the context of resume accolades, taking more courses generally isn't considered a resume accolade - there are far more effective (and obnoxious) things to do if someone wants to pad their resume. For example, in some clubs around campus, there are literally _three_ presidents of the club, which is an obvious way to pad a resume. The OP was not intending to do this. In fact, he even apologized because for some reason student responders made jokes.

not gonna say anything here except to call out this: "Re: "underrep minorities and minorities in general struggle everyday in this country". Research is hard enough too and requires a lot of effort, support, and ambition. It's just as easy to derail someone from a research career with bad experiences as it is with a minority. Same concept applies here. "

yes I know this, but it's a different type of struggle. Only a truly privileged person would try to equate the two difficulties and act like they are even of the same nature

Re: "Only a truly privileged person would try to equate the two difficulties and act like they are even of the same nature" - 
there was no equating here. There's no "greater than" or "less than" here, because they're apples and oranges. Nobody wants to make direct comparisons about "difficulty here", and there are many forms of difficulties.

But just because they're apples and oranges does not mean we should start deriding oranges...

Also, are you assuming the OP's post therefore means he's not underrep-minority, therefore he isn't deserving of respectful responses?

It's hilarious here how when someone is genuinely ambitious and interested in pursuing a career in research, the main student comments revolve around pulling down the guy. Especially when getting into the deep learning PhDs these days has dropped < 1% acceptance rates.

And some of the acceptees, have in fact "done graduate coursework" back in freshman year of college or even high school - there's already a handful of high school students who've won international competitions and had publications - why pull down the OP when he has to compete against these people, not the average EECS 101 responder to this thread? It's analogous to person A training for the olympics in running, and then person B tells A: "slow down dude, I can't even run a mile!" "Stop being so arrogant!" when person A has genuinely requested advice. 

First we have the "EECS MASTER RACE" culture which attacks people who don't do CS, and now "Slow down dude!" culture which attacks any ambitious person.

Is this really the community we need? Come on, we're better than this.

history.content:
I can see that this thread got posted on overheard. I apologize for any discomfort. 

Thanks follow ups for answering my question seriously.

When I made this post I did not think too much and simply dumped everything here. I really didn't meant to be offensive of any kind.

I thought 101 is an alternative to the private appointment with an major advisor but obviously ignored its effect.

Again, apologize to everyone.

history.subject: Classes for AI/Robotics (126, 106ab etc.) advice?

history.content:
Hi, I am a sophomore and wants to get some advice about what classes to take next. I am planning to get a PhD in Robotics / AI.

Tech Classes taken: CS61ABC, CS70, EE16AB, MATH53, STAT134 

Tech Classes taking: CS189, CS170, EECS127

Want to take: EECS126(see below), CS162, CS294-112, CS280, EE106A, EE106B, (EE120 if needed for 106ab), EECS227C, CS188(Self-study),  MATH104, other math upper divs if I do math major

So far I get A and A+ in all tech courses and feel 3 or 4 techs are easy to handle.

Q1: I know that EECS126 is very important in research and some labs prefer students who have taken it, it is also important to gain mathematical maturity from it. However, I have self-studied EECS126 thoroughly in summer before I take 189 and can understand every proof in Sahai's 189 notes, also taken stat134 and self-studied prob140. And I had taken 126 for 3 weeks(did all HWs) and feel comfortable with the content. The dilemma is, should I take it next semester? If so it might more like "practicing" instead of "learning" given previous effort on probabilities. If not, will I be disadvantaged in applying for research?

Q2: Should I double major in math? I am thinking about it because advanced math seems fundamental in research. However, it seems that EECS department has already offered math courses like EECS126 and 127, and I can either choose a few courses like MATH104 as a CS student or dive myself into math major. I know Robotics&AI requires extensive math but is not sure if the math courses in math major requirements are useful for them.

Q3: Are grad courses hard to enroll in? From the syllabus of them, I can see they are critical to research but I heard that these course are often over enrolled and it is hard for undergrad to get in. 

Q4: [For Prof Sahai if you are looking at it], CS189 changed its syllabus this semester and removed several topics like MLE/MAP derivation of minimization objective. I personally followed notes in Sp2018 and tried some of its HW about these missing topics. However, my friend told me that a lot of contents are not in those notes. Where can I self-study those removed materials? Will I miss anything if I just read the notes?
history.subject: Classes for AI/Robotics (126, 106ab etc.) advice?
